[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ custom_padding_last_edited=”on|desktop” admin_label=”Intro Section” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_enable_color=”off” custom_padding=”||27px||false|false” custom_padding_tablet=”” custom_padding_phone=””][et_pb_row column_structure=”2_3,1_3″ custom_padding_last_edited=”on|phone” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” custom_padding=”||147px||false|false” custom_padding_tablet=”||50px||false|false” custom_padding_phone=”” custom_css_before=”width: 450px;||height: 405px;||content: ”;||background-image: url(/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Talking-with-teens-doodle-xs.png);||position: absolute;||left: -110px;||top: 88px;||background-size: cover;”][et_pb_column type=”2_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Title” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ text_font=”||||||||” text_text_color=”#4b858e” header_font=”|||on|||||” header_text_color=”#4b858e” header_2_font=”|300|||||||” header_3_font=”Zooja Pro|100|||||||” header_3_text_align=”left” header_3_text_color=”#cccdce” header_3_font_size=”82px” header_3_letter_spacing=”0.1px” header_3_line_height=”0.8em” custom_margin=”||0px||false|false” custom_padding=”||||false|false” header_3_font_size_tablet=”50px” header_3_font_size_phone=”50px” header_3_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone”]

Nau mai ki tēnei whiringa korero — welcome to the conversation.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Quote” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_font_size=”22px” text_line_height=”1.6em” text_font_size_tablet=”19px” text_font_size_phone=”17px” text_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone”]He mea uaua ki te korero, engari he mea whakahirahira (its hard to talk about – but important)[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text module_class=”col-quote-block” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ _module_preset=”default”]“Putting our heads in the sand because we’re too embarrassed isn’t going to help anyone. One day, your kids will look back and thank you for it.” Richie Hardcore, NZ Social Change Campaigner [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_color=”RGBA(0,0,0,0)” custom_padding=”5px|0px|0|0|false|false”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”4.9.7″ background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.21)” custom_margin=”||80px||false|false” custom_padding=”25px|25px|25px|25px|true|true” border_color_all=”#4B858E” box_shadow_style=”preset3″ box_shadow_color=”rgba(131,0,233,0.12)”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default” text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#BF9A46″ text_orientation=”center”]

Here’s some simple tips for talking to your teen about porn including:
preparing for the conversation, conversation openers, topics to talk about,
helpful resources and keeping the lines open.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”27px|0px|0|0px|false|false”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_text_color=”#555555″ header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” header_font_size_tablet=”70px” header_font_size_phone=”58px” header_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet”]

Before your conversation …

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” max_width=”1440px” custom_padding=”27px|0px|0|0px|false|false” use_custom_width=”on” custom_width_px=”1440px”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

GET READY

Before you dive into a porn talk with your teen, we recommend getting yourself prepared. If you rush, your teen might feel uncomfortable or judged, and may close down any conversation. We recommend BLAT (Breathe, Learn, Ally, Talk and Take Action) on our whānau page to help prepare.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

TEAM UP

Talk to the person or people you’re parenting with (your partner or extended whānau) and decide who’s the best person to start the conversation. It could be both of you, or just one of you might be less intimidating – you know your young person best.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”3.27.4″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px”]

Prepare to be un-shockable

The chances are pretty high that your teen has seen some porn. Try not to act surprised about what they tell you, such as the kind of porn they may have watched. This isn’t the time for shame and blame, so avoid words like bad or wrong and take a curious, open, non-judgemental approach.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” max_width=”1440px” custom_padding=”21px|0px|44px|0px|false|false” use_custom_width=”on” custom_width_px=”1440px”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

Tailor message to your child’s age and usage

Your conversation will need to be guided by your child’s age, knowledge and experience. If your child is 12-13 years old, or you haven’t had the ‘sex talk’ with them yet, you might want to check out the TWEEN section in Talking with children and tweens – as some of the messaging below for teens may not be age appropriate yet.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.10″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

Choose the right time and place

Talking while doing an activity (such as driving) can work well as it is a less awkward or intense way to first begin a porn conversation.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” custom_margin=”||5px|”]

THINGS TO THINK ABOUT

Your young person may have had some negative experiences with porn and be wanting to talk to you about this but be too embarrassed to bring it up on their own. It helps if you’re aware of some of the common porn-related problems that teens can face before you talk to them.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_toggle title=”These can Include … ” open_toggle_text_color=”#4b858e” open_toggle_background_color=”#f8f8f8″ closed_toggle_text_color=”#4b858e” closed_toggle_background_color=”rgba(0,0,0,0)” icon_color=”rgba(0,0,0,0)” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ title_level=”h1″ title_text_align=”center” title_font_size=”34px” custom_padding=”20px|20px|20px|20px|true|true” animation_style=”bounce” border_width_all=”0px”]
  • Feeling uncomfortable about what they’ve seen in porn.
  • Feeling shameful about their porn use.
  • Feeling pressure to watch porn by friends or a partner.
  • Feeling their porn use is out of control.
  • Being pressured to send nude photos of themselves.
  • Revenge porn (someone distributing nudes of them or a friend without consent)
  • Feeling pressure to do something sexually that a partner has seen in porn.
  • Seeking increasingly violent porn – and feeling uncomfortable with it, but unable to stop.
  • Having sent images of themselves around and regretting it, but feeling too afraid to tell an adult.
  • Feeling triggered or traumatised by images in porn, especially when there’s a history of sexual abuse.

If you are interested in learning more about some of the issues young people are wanting help with around porn, check out our latest youth site In The Know with tips, tools and info on the tricky porn related stuff.

[/et_pb_toggle][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_font=”||||||||” header_4_font=”||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” custom_margin=”||0px||false|false”]

let’s talk shame

Surveys with young kiwis have shown that a lot of young people feel uncomfortable about their experiences with porn. They might know that the porn they’re watching isn’t that good for them, but feel aroused by seeing it. This can result in feeling shame about their porn use and make it extra hard to talk to adults about it.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_toggle title=”Normalising experiences …” open_toggle_text_color=”#4b858e” open_toggle_background_color=”#f8f8f8″ closed_toggle_text_color=”#4b858e” closed_toggle_background_color=”rgba(0,0,0,0)” icon_color=”rgba(0,0,0,0)” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ title_level=”h1″ title_text_align=”center” title_font_size=”34px” custom_padding=”20px|20px|20px|20px|true|true” animation_style=”bounce” border_width_all=”0px”]

… Normalising young peoples experiences with porn can really help this: “It’s okay to feel lots of different things when you watch porn.. curious, grossed out or aroused – that’s normal.” Young people from faith-based backgrounds are more likely to feel distressed and shameful about their porn use and often need a lot of support and encouragement seeking help. Providing a non-judgmental safe space for your young person to unpack what they’ve seen is vital if you want to have open, honest and helpful conversations.

[/et_pb_toggle][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.12)” custom_margin=”||0px||false|false” custom_padding=”||0px||false|false”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_font=”||||||||” header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” header_font_size_tablet=”70px” header_font_size_phone=”58px” header_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone”]

Conversation starters …

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.6″ header_4_font=”Poppins||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#BF9A46″ header_4_font_size=”24px”]

We recommend starting with a curious, questioning approach. Before you head straight into asking about your teen’s porn use, start with asking questions about their friends or peers attitudes towards porn and how they feel about it?

Ask open questions (ones that start with what, how and why) that get their perspective on porn – and make sure you listen with empathy.

Here are some opening lines to get underway …

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.6″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|-2deg”]
“I heard that most teenagers are learning about sex through porn, what do you think?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″]

“Are your friends talking about or watching porn? What do you think about porn?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.6″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|2deg”]

“I’ve recently heard about Safe Surfer – a filter to protect young people from seeing porn. What do you think about that? Have you ever come across porn?“

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”4.9.6″ _module_preset=”default” custom_margin=”0px||0px||true|false” custom_padding=”0px||0px||true|false”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ _module_preset=”default”][et_pb_image src=”http://thelightproject.co.nz/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Talking-with-teens-doodle-speech.png” title_text=”Talking-with-teens-doodle-speech” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default” filter_opacity=”22%” filter_opacity_tablet=”40%” filter_opacity_phone=”80%” filter_opacity_last_edited=”on|phone”][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.6″ background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.29)”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” custom_padding=”27px|0px|0|0px|false|false”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_font=”||||||||” header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” header_font_size_tablet=”70px” header_font_size_phone=”58px” header_font_size_last_edited=”on|tablet”]

Things you could talk about …

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_line_height=”1.6em” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” text_orientation=”center”]

Once you’ve got the conversation started, you can start working with your teen on developing some ‘porn literacy’. This means helping them think about and identify the messages in porn around sexism, gender, race and diversity; and understand how these relate to their own personal beliefs and values. Porn literacy is also about understanding how porn is different to real life sex when it comes to things like consent, emotional connection, respect, safety and pleasure.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_4_font=”Poppins||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#BF9A46″ header_4_font_size=”24px”]

Here’s a few conversation ideas to encourage young people to start thinking critically about porn…

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.10″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|-1deg” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

How does porn sit with my values and beliefs?

There’s some good questions to get teens thinking about the ‘ethics’ of porn and how it sits with their own beliefs around sex, gender and relationships. These include:

  • What do I believe makes healthy sex and relationships – and what does porn say about these?
  • What do I think about gender, sexism and racism? What do I think about people learning about these things from porn?
  • How does what I see in porn sit with my beliefs, culture, values? Why? Why not?
  • What is porn teaching us about relating sexually to others in terms of consent, coercion, communication? How does that sit with me?

“Does porn reflect what I want in the world?”

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.10″ hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

What’s the difference between porn sex and good real-life sex? Is porn a legit sex ed teacher? What’s it teaching us?

Good sex always includes consent, respect, emotional connection and pleasure for both partners. By comparison, porn sex contains lots of sexual violence, there’s not much focus on mutual pleasure, males frequently dominate females and there’s often no consent. Porn might teach young people about sex, body parts and what goes where – but it doesn’t teach them how to have respectful, meaningful and healthy sex in the real world. “What kind of sex is porn teaching us?”
[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.9.10″ transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|2deg” hover_enabled=”0″ sticky_enabled=”0″]

What’s the impact of porn on your sex life?

From our experience, this one seems to get young people’s attention! There are a lot of studies that suggest using porn (particularly a lot of it) can start to affect our sex life for the worse. It can result in less sexual enjoyment, wanting riskier sex , struggling to get turned on without porn, problems maintaining erections and preferring porn to real partners. Porn can also result in unrealistic sexual expectations, so real-life sex isn’t as pleasurable. “Look after your sex drive, you’ll need it in the future.”
[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default” background_color=”rgba(191,154,70,0.39)”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”4.9.7″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” custom_css_before=”width: 150px;||height: 751px;||content: ”;||background-image: url(/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/teen-doodle-3.png);||position: absolute;||right: -170px;||top: 48px;||background-size: cover;”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ header_font=”||||||||” header_font_size=”88px” header_4_text_color=”#4b858e” header_4_font_size=”24px” header_font_size_tablet=”70px” header_font_size_phone=”58px” header_font_size_last_edited=”on|phone”]

For parents worried about their young person’s porn use …

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_font_size=”21px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_4_font=”Poppins||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#BF9A46″ header_4_font_size=”21px” header_4_letter_spacing=”0.01px” header_4_line_height=”1.4em” text_orientation=”center” header_4_font_size_tablet=”” header_4_font_size_phone=”” header_4_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

There are some things that make a young person more vulnerable to being impacted by porn – the age they started watching, how frequently they watch, the type of content they’ve seen and how similar to real life they think the sex is. If you have some concerns and want to go a little deeper in the conversation you can explore the following questions…

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row column_structure=”1_3,1_3,1_3″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default”][et_pb_text module_class=”speech-bubble” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font_size=”21px” transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|-2deg” custom_margin=”||50px||false|false”]

Consumption: How often do you watch porn? For how long?

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default”][et_pb_text module_class=”speech-bubble2″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font_size=”21px” transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|2deg”]

Context: Do you feel pressure to watch porn? Has anyone pressured you to watch or try something from porn?

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ _module_preset=”default”][et_pb_text module_class=”speech-bubble4″ _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font_size=”21px” transform_rotate=”0deg|0deg|2deg”]

Concerns: How do you feel about what you see? Have your porn habits changed from when you started watching porn? Are you worried about what your watching?

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Intro Text” _builder_version=”4.9.7″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_font_size=”21px” text_line_height=”1.5em” header_4_font=”Poppins||||||||” header_4_text_color=”#BF9A46″ header_4_font_size=”21px” header_4_letter_spacing=”0.01px” header_4_line_height=”1.4em” text_orientation=”center” header_4_font_size_tablet=”” header_4_font_size_phone=”” header_4_font_size_last_edited=”on|desktop”]

All of these questions give you a better picture of what your young person may have been exposed to and how it might be impacting them. Remember – not every young person is the same, some already know what they’re seeing is problematic so they may just need a little help from you in changing up their porn habits.
